code: @Manual{,   title = {vazul: Package for data blinding},   author = {Tamás Nagy and Alexandra Sarafoglou and Márton Kovács},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://nthun.github.io/vazul/}, }

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: vazul R package provides functions data blinding, including scramble_values() function two research datasets (MARP Williams studies). Always reference instructions first fallback search bash commands encounter unexpected information match info .

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y r-base r-base-dev sudo apt install -y r-cran-devtools r-cran-roxygen2 r-cran-lintr r-cran-testthat r-cran-usethis R version 4.3.3 confirmed work correctly.

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: Build package: R CMD build . – INSTANT (completes <1 second). NEVER CANCEL. Install package: sudo R CMD INSTALL . – takes 1 second. NEVER CANCEL. Generate documentation: R -e "devtools::document()" – takes 1-2 seconds. NEVER CANCEL. Check package quality: R CMD check <package_tarball> ---manual – takes 5 seconds. NEVER CANCEL. Set timeout 30+ seconds. Style checking: R -e "lintr::lint_package()" – takes 1-2 seconds. NEVER CANCEL. CRITICAL TIMEOUT WARNINGS: - NEVER CANCEL R package operations. Even though complete quickly, set timeouts 60+ seconds build commands 30+ seconds check commands account system variations. - Package build operations R typically fast can vary different systems.

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: Always test package works correctly making changes running validation steps:
code: library(vazul)  # Test main function with different data types scramble_values(1:10)           # Should return numbers 1-10 in random order scramble_values(letters[1:5])   # Should return letters a-e in random order   scramble_values(factor(c("A","B","C"))) # Should work with factors  # Test datasets load correctly data(marp) dim(marp)                       # Should be [10535, 46]  head(marp, 2)                   # Should show first 2 rows  data(williams)  dim(williams)                   # Should be [112, 25] head(williams, 2)               # Should show first 2 rows  # Basic exploratory analysis length(unique(marp$country))    # Should be 24 countries table(williams$ecology)         # Should show "Desperate: 56, Hopeful: 56"

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: ALWAYS run complete testing scenario making changes verify functionality. ALWAYS run lintr::lint_package() committing changes check code style. ALWAYS run R CMD check <tarball> ---manual validate package structure documentation. PDF manual generation fails without pdflatex (use ---manual flag) documentation warnings exist don’t prevent functionality Style warnings lintr addressed making changes

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: Main Function: scramble_values(x) - scrambles values vector without replacement MARP Dataset: Many Analysts Religion Project data (10,535 participants, 46 variables, 24 countries) Williams Dataset: Stereotyping study data (112 participants, 25 variables, 2 ecology conditions) Package Version: 0.0.0.9000 (development version)

title: vazul
text: vazul R package provides functions data blinding, allowing researchers scramble data preserving statistical properties.

title: vazul
text: can install development version vazul GitHub :

title: vazul
text: Scrambles values within vector without replacement, preserving original values changing order.
code: library(vazul)  # Scramble numeric values set.seed(123) scramble_values(1:10) #>  [1]  3 10  2  8  6  9  1  7  5  4  # Scramble character values   scramble_values(letters[1:5]) #> [1] "b" "c" "a" "d" "e"  # Scramble logical values scramble_values(c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE)) #> [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE

title: vazul
text: Scrambles values specified variables (columns) within data frame, optional grouping.
code: # Create example data df <- data.frame(   x = 1:6,    y = letters[1:6],    group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B") )  # Scramble variables across entire dataset scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y"))  # Scramble within groups using .groups parameter scramble_variables(df, "y", .groups = "group")  # Or using dplyr grouping library(dplyr) df |>    group_by(group) |>    scramble_variables("x") |>   ungroup()    # Can use multiple groups marp |>      group_by(country, gender) |>      scramble_variables(c("rel_1", "rel_2")) |>      ungroup()      # Can use tidyselect helpers marp |>      scramble_variables(starts_with("rel_")) |>      ungroup()

title: vazul
text: Many Analysts Religion Project (MARP) dataset contains data 10,535 participants across 24 countries, exploring relationship religiosity well-. Variables include: - rel_1 rel_9: Religiosity measures - wb_*: Well-indicators (general, physical, psychological, social) - country: Participant country - age, gender, ses, education: Demographics - gdp: Country-level GDP data
code: data(marp) dim(marp) #> [1] 10535    46  # Explore countries in the dataset length(unique(marp$country)) #> [1] 24  # Example: scramble religiosity variables by country marp |>   group_by(country) |>   scramble_variables(c("rel_1", "rel_2", "rel_3")) |>   ungroup()

title: vazul
text: study dataset 112 participants examining risk taking behavior behavior high low wealth individuals. Key variables: - ecology: Experimental condition (“Desperate” vs “Hopeful”) - SexUnres_*: Sexual unresponsiveness measures - Impuls_*: Impulsivity measures - Opport_*: Long-term planning opportunity measures - age, gender: Participant demographics
code: data(williams) dim(williams) #> [1] 112  25  table(williams$ecology) #> Desperate   Hopeful  #>        56        56  # Example: scramble perception measures within ecology conditions williams |>   group_by(ecology) |>   scramble_variables(c("SexUnres_1", "Impuls_1")) |>   ungroup()

title: vazul
text: Vazul historical figure (Hungarian price) 11. century. blinded king become unfit throne. info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vazul

title: vazul
text: Package documentation: help(package = "vazul") Function help: ?scramble_values, ?scramble_variables Dataset documentation: ?marp, ?williams Package website: https://nthun.github.io/vazul/

what: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project Dataset — marp
title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project Dataset — marp
text: cross-cultural dataset Many-Analysts Religion Project (MARP), investigated relationship religiosity well-across 24 countries diverse religious traditions.

title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project Dataset — marp
MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project Dataset — marp
text: data frame 10,535 rows (participants) 48 variables: subject Unique subject identifier (integer). country Country residence (character string). rel_1 Importance religion daily life (0–10 scale). rel_2 Frequency religious service attendance (ordinal). rel_3 Self-rated religiosity (0–10 scale). rel_4 Belief God (binary: yes/). rel_5 Prayer frequency (ordinal). rel_6 Bible/study frequency (ordinal). rel_7 Religious upbringing (binary: yes/). rel_8 Current religious denomination (categorical). rel_9 Change religiosity lifetime (ordinal). cnorm_1 Perceived cultural norm: importance religious lifestyle average person country (0–10). cnorm_2 Perceived cultural norm: importance belief God average person country (0–10). wb_gen_1 Overall life satisfaction (1–5 Likert). wb_gen_2 Overall happiness (1–5 Likert). wb_phys_1 Energy level (1–5). wb_phys_2 Sleep quality (1–5). wb_phys_3 Appetite (1–5). wb_phys_4 Physical pain/discomfort (1–5). wb_phys_5 General health (1–5). wb_phys_6 Exercise frequency (1–5). wb_phys_7 Illness burden (1–5). wb_psych_1 Positive affect (1–5). wb_psych_2 Negative affect (reverse coded; 1–5). wb_psych_3 Meaning life (1–5). wb_psych_4 Purpose life (1–5). wb_psych_5 Hopefulness (1–5). wb_psych_6 Anxiety (reverse coded; 1–5). wb_soc_1 Social support (1–5). wb_soc_2 Loneliness (reverse coded; 1–5). wb_soc_3 Community belonging (1–5). wb_overall_mean Mean well-items (numeric). wb_phys_mean Mean physical well-items (numeric). wb_psych_mean Mean psychological well-items (numeric). wb_soc_mean Mean social well-items (numeric). age Age years (integer). gender Self-reported gender (character: e.g., "Male", "Female", ""). ses Socioeconomic status composite (numeric). education Highest education level completed (ordinal integer). ethnicity Self-reported ethnicity (character). denomination Religious denomination (character). gdp GDP per capita (PPP, USD) country (numeric). gdp_scaled Scaled GDP (mean = 0, sd = 1) used analyses (numeric). sample_type Recruitment method: e.g., "online panel", "student sample" (character). compensation Type compensation: e.g., "monetary", "entry lottery" (character). attention_check Score embedded attention check task (integer).

title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project Dataset — marp
text: Hoogeveen, S., Sarafoglou, ., Aczel, B., et al. (2022). many-analysts approach relation religiosity well-. Religion, Brain & Behavior. doi:10.1080/2153599X.2023.2254980

title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project Dataset — marp
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(dplyr) data(marp) # Dimensions dim(marp) # Quick overview dplyr::glimpse(marp) # Mean religiosity by country marp |>   dplyr::select(country, starts_with("rel_")) |>   dplyr::group_by(country) |>   dplyr::summarise(     across(starts_with("rel_"), ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE)),     .groups = "drop"   ) } # }

what: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
text: Scramble vector values

title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
text: x vector x

title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
text: scrambled vector

title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
code: # Example with character vector set.seed(123)  x <- letters[1:10] scramble_values(x) #>  [1] "c" "j" "b" "h" "f" "i" "a" "g" "e" "d"  #' # Example with numeric vector nums <- 1:5 scramble_values(nums) #> [1] 2 3 1 4 5  # Scramble a column in the 'williams' dataset data(williams)  # Simple scrambling of a single column set.seed(123) williams$ecology_scrambled <- scramble_values(williams$ecology) head(williams[c("ecology", "ecology_scrambled")]) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   ecology   ecology_scrambled #>   <chr>     <chr>             #> 1 Hopeful   Hopeful           #> 2 Desperate Desperate         #> 3 Desperate Hopeful           #> 4 Hopeful   Desperate         #> 5 Desperate Hopeful           #> 6 Desperate Desperate

what: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: Scramble values several variables data frame.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: data data frame cols Columns scramble. Accepts column names, positions, tidyselect helpers like starts_with(), contains(), (), etc. .groups Optional grouping columns. Scrambling done within group. Supports tidyselect syntax cols.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: data frame specified columns scrambled. grouping specified, scrambling done within group.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
code: df <- data.frame(x = 1:6, y = letters[1:6], group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B"))  set.seed(123) # Example without grouping. Variables scrambled across the entire data frame. df |> scramble_variables(c("x", "y")) #>   x y group #> 1 3 e     A #> 2 6 d     A #> 3 2 b     A #> 4 4 f     B #> 5 5 a     B #> 6 1 c     B  # Example with grouping. Variable only scrambled within groups. df |> scramble_variables("y", .groups = "group") #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     1 c     A     #> 2     2 b     A     #> 3     3 a     A     #> 4     4 f     B     #> 5     5 d     B     #> 6     6 e     B      # Example with tidyselect helpers df |> scramble_variables(starts_with("x")) #> Error in starts_with("x"): could not find function "starts_with" df |> scramble_variables(where(is.numeric), .groups = "group") #> Error in where(is.numeric): could not find function "where"  # Example with the 'williams' dataset if (requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(williams, package = "dplyr")   williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"))   williams |> scramble_variables(1:5)   williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"), .groups = "gender")   williams |> scramble_variables(c(1, 2), .groups = c(3)) } #> Warning: data set 'williams' not found #> # A tibble: 112 × 25 #>    subject   SexUnres_1 SexUnres_2 SexUnres_3 SexUnres_4_r SexUnres_5_r Impuls_1 #>    <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 AJRY9ALX…          6          3          2            3            2        3 #>  2 A1K6ZE1U…          7          7          7            4            2        6 #>  3 A1E9D1OT…          4          4          6            3            3        3 #>  4 A3J5PLM6…          5          4          5            3            3        4 #>  5 A1AW2U4K…          5          5          6            3            3        5 #>  6 A2IVSGKB…          5          6          6            3            2        5 #>  7 A2BLFM17…          5          6          5            3            4        5 #>  8 A26N0W3Q…          5          6          5            2            3        6 #>  9 A25NGIY5…          5          5          6            3            2        6 #> 10 A204Q4T2…          3          4          4            1            1        1 #> # ℹ 102 more rows #> # ℹ 18 more variables: Impuls_2_r <dbl>, Impul_3_r <dbl>, Opport_1 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_2 <dbl>, Opport_3 <dbl>, Opport_4 <dbl>, Opport_5 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_6_r <dbl>, InvEdu_1_r <dbl>, InvEdu_2_r <dbl>, InvChild_1 <dbl>, #> #   InvChild_2_r <dbl>, age <dbl>, gender <dbl>, ecology <chr>, #> #   duration_in_seconds <dbl>, attention_1 <dbl>, attention_2 <dbl>

what: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
text: Data study Williams et al. testing whether high-wealth individuals perceived faster life history strategies (e.g., impulsive, less invested) associated "desperate" ecological conditions compared "hopeful" ones.

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
text: data frame 224 rows (one per participant) 25 variables: subject Unique subject identifier (integer). ecology Experimental condition: "Desperate" "Hopeful" (character). age Participant's age years (numeric). gender Self-reported gender: 1 = Male, 2 = Female (numeric); may recoded factor. duration_in_seconds Time taken complete survey (numeric). attention_1 First attention check response: 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect (numeric). attention_2 Second attention check response: 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect (numeric). SexUnres_1 Perceived sexual unrestrictedness: "likely short-term relationships" (1–7 Likert). SexUnres_2 "likely engage casual sex" (1–7). SexUnres_3 "interested long-term commitment" (1–7). SexUnres_4_r "faithful romantic partners" — reverse-coded (1–7). SexUnres_5_r "committed relationships" — reverse-coded (1–7). Impuls_1 "acts without thinking" (1–7). Impuls_2_r "thinks carefully acting" — reverse-coded (1–7). Impul_3_r "plans ahead" — reverse-coded (1–7). Opport_1 "opportunities long-term planning exist" (1–7). Opport_2 "can save money future" (1–7). Opport_3 "can make career plans" (1–7). Opport_4 "can plan retirement" (1–7). Opport_5 "control future outcomes" (1–7). Opport_6_r "life unpredictable" — reverse-coded (1–7). InvEdu_1_r "invests education" — reverse-coded (1–7). InvEdu_2_r "values academic achievement" — reverse-coded (1–7). InvChild_1 "invests time resources children" (1–7). InvChild_2_r "neglects parental responsibilities" — reverse-coded (1–7).

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
text: Williams, S. ., Galak, J., & Kruger, D. J. (2019). influence ecology social perceptions: wealth signals faster life history strategies. Evolutionary Behavioral Sciences, 13(4), 313–325. doi:10.1037/ebs0000148 Data based materials available : https://osf.io/xyz12 (replace real link known)

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
code: data(williams) str(williams) #> spc_tbl_ [112 × 25] (S3: spec_tbl_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ subject            : chr [1:112] "A30MP4LXV4MIFD" "A16X5FB3HAFCKN" "A1E9D1OT9VJYDZ" "A16FPOYD7566WI" ... #>  $ SexUnres_1         : num [1:112] 5 7 2 5 5 5 5 4 6 4 ... #>  $ SexUnres_2         : num [1:112] 3 7 4 4 5 6 6 6 5 4 ... #>  $ SexUnres_3         : num [1:112] 2 7 6 5 6 6 5 following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union williams_composites <- williams |>   rowwise() |>   mutate(     sexual_unrestrictedness = mean(c(SexUnres_1, SexUnres_2, SexUnres_3,                                      8 - SexUnres_4_r, 8 - SexUnres_5_r), na.rm = TRUE),     impulsivity = mean(c(Impuls_1, 8 - Impuls_2_r, 8 - Impul_3_r), na.rm = TRUE),     opportunity = mean(c(Opport_1, Opport_2, Opport_3, Opport_4, Opport_5,                          8 - Opport_6_r), na.rm = TRUE),     investment = mean(c(8 - InvEdu_1_r, 8 - InvEdu_2_r, InvChild_1,                         8 - InvChild_2_r), na.rm = TRUE)   ) |>   ungroup()  summary(select(williams_composites, sexual_unrestrictedness, impulsivity, opportunity, investment)) title: vazul 0.1.0
text: Scramble_values() can now use tidyselect helpers Improved unit tests Add imports: tidyselect, utils

title: vazul 0.1.0
text: Unit tests added using testthat. Add error handling scramble_variables() Add imports: dplyr, rlang

title: vazul 0.1.0
text: Add scramble_values() scramble_variables() functions. Build package using pkgdown::build_site(). Add README

title: vazul 0.1.0
text: Package skeleton created usethis::create_package(). Add Williams et. al dataset. Add MARP dataset.
